briefOverview: A dedicatory prayer for the Kirtland Temple asks God to accept the house, empower the worshipers, advance missionary work, protect the Saints, and move forward the gathering of Israel.
summary: The prayer thanks God for commanding the temple’s construction and asks Him to accept and sanctify the house so that His presence may rest there. It petitions that worshipers be taught wisdom, learn by study and faith, be organized according to divine law, and be endowed with spiritual gifts and power for missionary work. It pleads for purity in the house, for repentance and restoration when transgression occurs, and for God’s protection against slander and violent opposition. The prayer calls for Pentecost-like manifestations, for the success of the gospel throughout the earth, and for blessings upon rulers and nations so the work might prosper. It intercedes for those driven from their lands in Missouri, asks for the redemption of Zion, and prays for the gathering and redemption of Israel, including Judah and the remnants of Jacob. It concludes with blessings upon Joseph Smith, church leaders, and all Saints, culminating in a doxology and the formal acceptance of the house and church by God.
externalContext: This prayer was offered by Joseph Smith on March 27, 1836, at the dedication of the Kirtland Temple in Ohio—the first temple built by the early Latter-day Saints. In 1833, church members had been expelled from Jackson County, Missouri, which the Saints believed was designated as Zion; this informs the pleas for deliverance and redemption. The prayer’s “solemn assembly” reflects biblical and early Christian patterns of sacred convocations. Its invocation of constitutional principles mirrors the Saints’ appeal to legal protections in the United States during the 1830s. Reports from the Kirtland dedication and subsequent meetings describe charismatic spiritual manifestations that participants associated with divine approval of the temple.
externalReferences: The language and petitions deliberately echo biblical temple and prophetic themes, such as a “house of prayer” (Isaiah 56:7) and God’s protective promise that “no weapon … shall prosper” (Isaiah 54:17). The request for Pentecost-like gifts—“cloven tongues as of fire” and a “rushing mighty wind”—draws directly from Acts 2:1–4. The prayer’s missional and eschatological imagery evokes Isaiah’s “seal up the law, bind up the testimony” (Isaiah 8:16), Daniel’s stone “cut out without hands” that becomes a great mountain (Daniel 2:34–35, 44–45), and the hope of being “caught up … in the clouds” to meet the Lord (1 Thessalonians 4:16–17). Its imagery of the church “fair as the moon, clear as the sun, and terrible as an army with banners” reflects Song of Solomon 6:10, and the vision of worshipers with palms and crowns recalls Revelation 7:9–10.
practicalQuestions: How can my places of worship and service more fully become a house of prayer, learning, and order?
What does it look like in practice to seek learning by study and also by faith in my current circumstances?
How can I keep my “incomings” and “outgoings” in the Lord’s name—aligning daily routines with sacred commitments?
Where do I need to balance prayers for mercy with trust in divine justice toward opposition and slander?
How might I support the gathering of God’s people—locally and globally—through testimony, service, and peacemaking?
What spiritual gifts should I seek to better fulfill my responsibilities, and how can I prepare to receive them?
uncertainAreas: The precise scope of phrases like “seal up the law, and bind up the testimony” and how the petition that “Jerusalem… may begin to be redeemed” was expected to unfold historically are interpretively open. The extent to which the protection promised against enemies is conditional on collective faithfulness is implied but not exhaustively defined.
